lines.text: Come on, Rabbit. Let's you and me bounce, huh?
Good heavens! M-m-m-me bounce?
Why, certainly! And look, you've got the feet for it.
I have?
Sure! Come on, try it! It makes ya feel just grrreat!

[chuckles]
Well, Tigger, your bouncing really got you into trouble this time.

[puzzled]
Say, who're you?
I'm the narrator.

[pleads desperately]
Oh well, please, for goodness sakes, narrate me down from here!
Very well. Hold on tight.
[turns the book sideways as Tigger whimpers in fright]
You can let go now, Tigger.

[stammers in panic, then covers his eyes]
N-n-n-n-n-n-n-never!
But Tigger, look for yourself. You're perfectly safe.
[Tigger peeks down at the text, then gingerly lets go of the tree, and sits on the text as the narrator chuckles]
What did I tell you, Tigger?
[Tigger smiles]
Come on.
[turns the book again, this time slanted]
There we go!
[Tigger whimpers as he slides down the text, then lands in the snow]
Tigger! B-b-but you're supposed to be lost.

[patting Rabbit's cheeks]
Aw, tiggers never get lost, Bunny Boy.

[dazed]
Never... get... lost?
Of course not!
Oh, no.
Hello, Rabbit! I'm Tigger. T-I double guh...
Please! Please! Don't spell it! Oh dear, will you just... just look at my beautiful garden!
Yyyyyuck! M-messy, isn't it?
Messy? Messy? It's ruined! It's ruined, Tigger! Why won't you ever stop bouncing?
Why? That's what Tiggers do best! Hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo!
Pooh, for a bear of very little brain, you sure are a smart one.
Pooh! Haven't you been listening to what Rabbit's been saying?
I listened, but then I had a small piece of fluff in my ear. Could you say it again, please, Rabbit?
Well, where should I start from?
Well, from the moment the fluff got in my ear.
Well, when was that?
I don't know. I couldn't hear properly.
You're next, Tigger. Jump!
Er, jump? Tiggers don't jump, they bounce.
Then bounce down.
Don't be "ridick-orous". Tiggers only bounce up!
You can climb down, Tigger.
Ah, but tiggers can't climb down, uh, uh, because, uh, oh... oh their tails get in the way!
Hooray! That settles it. If he won't jump, and he can't climb down, then we'll just have to leave him up there forever!
Look, l-look, Piglet. There's something in that tree over there.
Is it one of the f-f-fiercer animals?
Halloo!

[lifting Piglet]
Yes. It's a "jagular."
W-What do "jagulars" d-do, Pooh?

[as he drops Piglet]
Well, "jagulars" always call, "Halloo!" And when you look up, they drop on you.
I'm looking *down*, P-P-Pooh.
I "recoggonize" you. You're the one that's stuffed with fluff.
Yeah. And you're sitting on it.
Yeah. And it's comfy, too!
ta-ta for now!

[singing; repeated lines]
The wonderful thing about tiggers / Is tiggers are wonderful things / Their tops are made out of rubber / Their bottoms are made out of springs / They're bouncy, trouncy, flouncy, pouncy, fun, fun, fun, fun, fun / But the most wonderful thing about tiggers is I'm the only one / IIIII'm the only one!
[growls]
Don't swing on a string / It's much too frail / The best kind of swing / Is a tigger's tail. Whee!
What's the matter, Tigger?
Phew. Oh, thank goodness. I was just getting a little seasick from...
[gulps]
seeing too much.
Uh, R-Rabbit?
Yes?
Say, Rabbit, how would it be if as soon as we're out of sight of this old pit, we just try to find it again?
What's the good of that?
Well, you see, we keep looking for home, but we keep finding this pit, so I just thought that if we looked for this pit, we might find home.
Hm, I don't see much sense in that. If I were to walk away from this pit, and then walk back to it - of course I should find it! I'll prove it to you! Wait here!
[marches away]
[Pooh's tummy rumbles]
W-w-what was that, Pooh?

[laughs]
My tummy rumbled. Now then - come on, let's go home.
But Pooh, do you know the way?
No, Piglet, but I've got twelve pots of honey in my cupboard, and they've been calling to my tummy.
They have?
Yes, Piglet. I couldn't hear them before because Rabbit would talk. I think I know where they're calling from, so come on. We'll just follow my tummy.

[bounces on Piglet]
Hello, Piglet! I'm Tigger!
Oh, Tigger! You sc-c-c-cared me!
Oh, shucks! That was just one of my little bounces!
It was? Oh. Thank you, Tigger.
Yeah, I'm saving my best bounce for ole Long Ears!
[pulling his ears, then dashing away]
Ta-ta!
I bet you can climb trees, huh, Tigger?
Climb trees? Hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo! Why, that's what Tiggers do best! Only Tiggers don't climb trees, they *bounce* 'em! C'mon, let's go! Hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo!

[looking for Pooh, Rabbit and Piglet who are hiding in a hollow log]
That's funny. They must be lost.
[yells into the log]

[echoes repeatedly]
HELLO! Hey, you blokes! Where are ya?

[sort of loudly]
In...
[Rabbit grabs his mouth]

[whispers]
Shush!

[whispers]
I am shushed!
we'll take Tigger for a long explore, see, somewhere he's never been before. And we'll lose him there!

[awakes]
Lose him?

Oh, we'll find him again next morning, and mark my words, he'll be a humble Tigger, a small and sad Tigger, and a "oh, rabbit, am I glad to see you" Tigger. And it'll take the bounces out of him, that's what! Now, all in favor, say 'aye'.
Aye.
[Pooh falls asleep again]
Pooh.
[shakes Pooh awake]
Pooh!

[waking up, then raising his hand]
Oh, here.
Oh-ho-ho, good. Just good. Motion carried.
Hello, Pooh. Hello, Piglet. What's up?

[pointing up to Tigger and Roo]
Tigger and Roo are up.
Oh, my goodness! Roo, how did you get up there?
Easy, Mama. We bounced up.
Oh, my goodness. Do be careful, dear!
I'm all right, Mama, but Tigger's stuck.
Oh, what a shame. That's too bad.
No, that's good. You see, he can't bounce anybody up there.
Oh, dear. We'll just have to get him down somehow.
Down? Down? Do we have to?
If I ever get outta this, I promise never to bounce again! N-Never!
I heard that, Tigger!
[to Christopher Robin, Piglet, and Pooh, hurriedly questioning them]
He promised! Did you hear him promise? I heard him! I heard him! You heard him, didn't ya? Didn't ya?
Christopher Robin, I like the old, bouncy Tigger best.
[cut to Tigger sadly walking away]
So do I, Roo.
I do, too.
Me, too.
Of course, we all do. Don't you agree, Rabbit?
I uh...
Well, Rabbit?
Well, uh, uh, that is, I-uh, what I mean...
Well?
Uh, I uh...
[sighs]
Oh, all right. I guess I like the old Tigger better, too.

[Pounces Rabbit]
Oh, boy! You mean I can have my bounce back? Hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo!

[as Roo is swinging on his tail]
S-s-s-s-s-stop that, kid! Please!
[cut to his point of view]
S-T-O-P, stop! You're rockin' the forest!

[scooping up snow]
Oh, good old terra firma!
[kisses the snow]
Say, I'm so happy I feel like bouncing!
[starts bouncing, but pauses when Rabbit interuppts him]
Uh-uh-uh! You promised! You promised!

[defeatedly falls back to the ground]
Oh, I did, didn't I? You mean I-I can't - ever bounce again?
Never!

[whimpering]
N-Never?
[brief silence]
N-Not even just - one, teensy-weensy bounce?

[defiantly]
Not even a *smidgen* of a bounce!
Meanwhile, Rabbit was still wandering around in the mist. By now, he was lost and bewildered. And to make matters worse, his mind was beginning to play tricks on him.
So Rabbit was now a humiliated Rabbit, a lost-and-found Rabbit, and a 'Why, oh why do these things happen to me?' Rabbit.

[emerging from the snow after crashing into Rabbit's house while ice skating with Roo]
Uh, pew! Ree-yuck! Tiggers don't like ice skating!

[after he tries to jump out of the book while climbing a tree with Roo]
Hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo! I almost bounced clear outta the book! Some bouncin', huh?
[looks down, then gasps as he clings to the tree for dear life]
Say, how did this tree get so high?
And so it seemed to be. There were the tracks joining each other here, getting mixed up with each other there. But to Pooh, quite plainly, there were small sets of paw marks.
So Pooh and Piglet waited in the mist for Rabbit. And then they waited... and waited... and waited. And all the while, Pooh's thoughts kept returning to his honey pots at home.
